channel.title: USB freezes when trying to access
channel.description:
First sorry if this is the wrong section, I couldn't see anywhere else to put it but I think this is my last hope posting here ^^.
Anyways, whenever I try to do ANYTHING with my usb stick, the explorer/program will just freeze completely until it is unplugged. Right clicking the drive, uninstalling the drive, opening it. Anything.
I've tried every solution on google and nothing seems to work.
I have tried to run my computer in safe mode and reformat the drive but nothing works. This happened shortly after I cleaned it out and started to add new files.
Anyone have any ideas/solutions how to fix this?

item.title: USB freezes when trying to access
item.dc:creator: @ohokay ohokay
item.description:
@ohokay wrote:

SilentCJ:

Ahh, that would be the reason. Have you no separate stick at all? Even an external hard drive will do, or a writeable CD, it’s always handy to have a Ubuntu installation around anyway.

Alright I’ll buy either a new memory stick or CDs today so I can try it out.

Read full topic
item.source: USB freezes when trying to access

item.source: USB freezes when trying to access

item.title: USB freezes when trying to access
item.dc:creator: @ohokay ohokay
item.description:
@ohokay wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:16, topic:511737”][quote author=ohokay link=topic=629982.msg4271929#msg4271929 date=1364595953]

Try it with a Linux installation, I imagine that would work, copy what you need from it, reformat it to FAT32 and copy the files back over.

You can use a Live installation (doesn’t actually need installing, just runs from a form of removable media e.g. copied CD or memory stick).

Info on Ubuntu and trying before installing: http://www.ubuntu.com/download/help/try-ubuntu-before-you-install
Creating a bootable Ubuntu USB memory stick: http://www.ubuntu.com/download/help/create-a-usb-stick-on-windows

Make sure you change the boot order to boot from the USB/CD, and then you can use the GParted application to format the stick.

Sounds like a whole lot of effort just for a memory stick haha, but it shouldn’t take too long.

Oh and the OS is completely free don’t worry.

That seemed pretty legit so I gave it a go. Turned out that even when I select the drive on the installation the program freezes…
[/quote]
Could I ask for a little more information?
Did you install the bootable disc onto a separate memory stick? Or is that after you’re actually in the OS?[/quote]

I don’t have a separate stick at the moment so I tried to install it on the “broken” one, I select the .iso and then browse to a drive. When I click on the drive, the program will freeze.

Read full topic
item.source: USB freezes when trying to access

item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“ohokay, post:15, topic:511737”][quote author=SilentCJ link=topic=629982.msg4271879#msg4271879 date=1364593014]
Try it with a Linux installation, I imagine that would work, copy what you need from it, reformat it to FAT32 and copy the files back over.

You can use a Live installation (doesn’t actually need installing, just runs from a form of removable media e.g. copied CD or memory stick).

Info on Ubuntu and trying before installing: http://www.ubuntu.com/download/help/try-ubuntu-before-you-install
Creating a bootable Ubuntu USB memory stick: http://www.ubuntu.com/download/help/create-a-usb-stick-on-windows

Make sure you change the boot order to boot from the USB/CD, and then you can use the GParted application to format the stick.

Sounds like a whole lot of effort just for a memory stick haha, but it shouldn’t take too long.

Oh and the OS is completely free don’t worry.
[/quote]

That seemed pretty legit so I gave it a go. Turned out that even when I select the drive on the installation the program freezes…[/quote]
Could I ask for a little more information?
Did you install the bootable disc onto a separate memory stick? Or is that after you’re actually in the OS?

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @ohokay ohokay
item.description:
@ohokay wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:13, topic:511737”]Try it with a Linux installation, I imagine that would work, copy what you need from it, reformat it to FAT32 and copy the files back over.

You can use a Live installation (doesn’t actually need installing, just runs from a form of removable media e.g. copied CD or memory stick).

Info on Ubuntu and trying before installing: http://www.ubuntu.com/download/help/try-ubuntu-before-you-install
Creating a bootable Ubuntu USB memory stick: http://www.ubuntu.com/download/help/create-a-usb-stick-on-windows

Make sure you change the boot order to boot from the USB/CD, and then you can use the GParted application to format the stick.

Sounds like a whole lot of effort just for a memory stick haha, but it shouldn’t take too long.

Oh and the OS is completely free don’t worry.[/quote]

That seemed pretty legit so I gave it a go. Turned out that even when I select the drive on the installation the program freezes…

[quote=“Lil_Smok3r, post:14, topic:511737”][quote author=SilentCJ link=topic=629982.msg4271879#msg4271879 date=1364593014]
Try it with a Linux installation, I imagine that would work, copy what you need from it, reformat it to FAT32 and copy the files back over.

You can use a Live installation (doesn’t actually need installing, just runs from a form of removable media e.g. copied CD or memory stick).

Info on Ubuntu and trying before installing: http://www.ubuntu.com/download/help/try-ubuntu-before-you-install
Creating a bootable Ubuntu USB memory stick: http://www.ubuntu.com/download/help/create-a-usb-stick-on-windows

Make sure you change the boot order to boot from the USB/CD, and then you can use the GParted application to format the stick.

Sounds like a whole lot of effort just for a memory stick haha, but it shouldn’t take too long.

Oh and the OS is completely free don’t worry.
[/quote]
You know a lot.

OT: Buy a new memory stick.[/quote]

Yes I know that’s an option… But I was wondering how to get the one I currently have fixed.

Read full topic

item.title: USB freezes when trying to access
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Try it with a Linux installation, I imagine that would work, copy what you need from it, reformat it to FAT32 and copy the files back over.

You can use a Live installation (doesn’t actually need installing, just runs from a form of removable media e.g. copied CD or memory stick).

Info on Ubuntu and trying before installing: http://www.ubuntu.com/download/help/try-ubuntu-before-you-install
Creating a bootable Ubuntu USB memory stick: http://www.ubuntu.com/download/help/create-a-usb-stick-on-windows

Make sure you change the boot order to boot from the USB/CD, and then you can use the GParted application to format the stick.

Sounds like a whole lot of effort just for a memory stick haha, but it shouldn’t take too long.

Oh and the OS is completely free don’t worry.

item.source: USB freezes when trying to access

item.title: USB freezes when trying to access
item.dc:creator: @ohokay ohokay
item.description:
@ohokay wrote:

[quote=“OBEYxChronik, post:10, topic:511737”]Oh, okay. Try this; http://www.fixya.com/support/t2261405-explorer_crashes_when_insert_usb_flash

and let me know if it works! If not, i’ll keep sending things your way till it does work![/quote]

Have already tried, there is no auto-run so I can’t explore.

[quote=“Travas, post:11, topic:511737”][quote author=Flame_ link=topic=629982.msg4271595#msg4271595 date=1364579957]
Either your computer doesn’t have the corresponding ports to the USB version, or the USB stick itself is corrupt.
[/quote]USBs are backwards compatible.

EDIT: Make sure Plug N Play is running correctly. [font=arial][size=15px]Start -> Run -> [/size][/font][font=arial][size=15px]services.msc[/size][/font][/quote]

It’s running fine.

Read full topic

item.source: USB freezes when trying to access

item.title: USB freezes when trying to access
item.dc:creator: @ohokay ohokay
item.description:
@ohokay wrote:

OBEYxChronik:

Something that’s in the USB might not be compatable with your CPU. If it’s an actual crash (system dump) you should get a blue screen. If you can tell me what the blue screen says, and i’ll be able to sort the problem out for you.

Not a system crash, just the explorer.exe or the program I’m trying to open it with, i.e Computer management.

And I’m sure it is, I’ve used it on this computer before perfectly fine.

Read full topic

@ohokay wrote:

[quote=“Lil_Smok3r, post:5, topic:511737”]I have a USB stuck into my port right now :).

OT: The metal part (the part that goes in) might be corrupt(as Flame_ said)[/quote]

No, it’s not.

The computer recognizes the drive just fine, says that it’s installed correctly. I just can’t open it without crashing.

I’m running it off a 2.0 port and it says the device is working perfectly fine.

I’ve tried it on about 5 different computers and the same outcome.

The USB was working fine before I started to put new files on it, now it’s broke.

Is there any way to fix this?
